awd_titl_txt: A control-theoretic framework for analysis and design of networked systems with strategic agents via structured strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
For the proper functioning of modern societal networks it is critical to incentivize strategically minded users participating in these networks to voluntarily act in the interest of the collective. Examples of such networks arise in intelligent transportation systems, electronic commerce, smart energy grid and energy markets, and spectrum allocation in wireless systems. These systems are being dramatically transformed by the ever-expanding use of electronic connectivity and computation so that increasingly sophisticated approaches can be applied for engineering these networks. This proposal aims to study these networked systems as stochastic dynamical systems with strategic agents having multiple interactions in the presence of partial information about the system and each other. In particular, the goal is to develop a control-theoretic framework to advance the state of the art for the analysis of such systems, and also to design novel incentive schemes that drive the agents' actions towards desirable social objectives. The research will be tightly integrated with a significant education and outreach program consisting of two focus areas: training students, including undergraduates and underrepresented minorities, in interdisciplinary research; and broadly disseminating research outcomes in the form of new curricular development and student involvement. 

The proposal will pursue two synergistic thrusts, one focusing on analysis and the other on design. The analysis thrust consists of investigating a control-theoretic framework that will enable the systematic evaluation of the agents' equilibrium strategies and beliefs, by modeling their interactions as a dynamic game with asymmetric and imperfect information. Specifically, we plan to develop a systematic methodology for finding Perfect Bayesian Equilibria for a broad class of dynamic games with asymmetric information. The associated analysis builds upon foundations in game theory, decentralized stochastic control, Markov decision processes and optimization. We envision a theoretical framework that supports analytical tools for the evaluation of equilibria much like the well-established backward dynamic programming tools for Markov decision processes. The design thrust consists of investigating incentives that induce agents to have an equilibrium behavior consistent with a socially optimal objective, and developing new dynamic mechanism design methodologies. Here, we will build upon the work on dynamic games by exploring applications of the systematic methodology developed in the analysis thrust to dynamic mechanism design. Specifically, we will investigate indirect dynamic mechanisms that are appropriate for realistic models with agents having large private type-sets but small action sets. Furthermore, we will investigate Lagrangian relaxation methods that allow for an easier and more general analysis of dynamic mechanism design with time-average constraints.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we developed broad insights for systems where multiple strategic agents interact over time and in a dynamic manner (sometimes over a network). The applications of this research apply to many application domains arising in engineering systems and economic systems, where there is dynamic state and multiple interactions between strategic agents that result in the evolution of the state. Some of these are: transportation systems, smart grids, electronic reputations systems, crowdsourcing system, ride-sharing systems, etc. Therefore, understanding how users behave and how the underlying mechanisms have to be designed is critical to the well-functioning of these societally important cyber-physical systems. Core to this understanding is the study of strategic information propagation in these systems.

Our findings can be broadly summarized as follows:

1. We develop methodologies to study the equilibrium behaviour of strategic agents in dynamic environments. The equilibria have a very desirable structure: each agent does not have to recall her entire history of actions in order to make a decision. Instead, she can summarize her entire history into appropriate quantities (sufficient statistics) which are her updated beliefs about the unobserved part of the system. Moreover, these quantities can be easily upadted and are public information.

2. The framework of Mechanism Design (MD) aims to bridge the informational gap between a designer, who wishes to achieve “efficient” resource allocation and agents, who are strategic and posses private information relevant to determining the efficient allocation and may not want to reveal it.  There are two very important features of practical mechanisms that are the focus of our investigation. The first is the informational constraint between agents - most mechanisms define the "contract" such that messages (bids) from all agents need to be collected centrally in order to determine each agents’ outcome. The second is related to the fact that, there is little to no guarantee that agents can dynamically learn about each others’ private information in order to calculate the equilibrium induced by the mechanism. Addressing the two features together can make a mechanism ready for application to scenarios where agents are distributed - both physically and informationally. We have developed mechanisms that have the following informational properties: the allocation and taxation function required by each agent depends only on messages (bids) of neighborhing agents in a network. This way there is no need for all bids to be transmitted to a central authority, a task that would create congestion in large decentralized networks. In addition, we have developed mechanisms that have convergenece guarantees, i.e., assuming that the agents interact sequentially over time by exchanging messages within a relatively large class, the mechanism guarantees convergence to the designed equilibrium. We have applied these ideas to mechanisms for private goods (Walrasian allocation with money) and public goods (Lindahl allocation) problems in the presence of strategic agents. We have applied these designs to mechanisms relevant for unicast and multicast transmission on the Internet and, for general convex optimization problems with linear constraints.

3. Social learning problems mathemtically abstract the interactions that occur in e-commerce platforms, recommendation systems and also cyberphysical systems. Here agents use private information and information about other agent to take actions. In this context we develop minimal communication rate based information aggregation protocols that work to yield learning even with strategic agents.

4. Information aggregation and disseminatjon are important facets of the functioning of the exemplary cyber-physical systems. Systems will fully strategic users may get bottlenecked during information aggregstion owing to phenomena such as information cascades (which we show in 3. can be overcome using sophisticated protocols) but backing away from fully rational procedures usually results in fast convergence. However, we demonstrate that the learning procedure can then be sabotaged easily via bot-like malicious agents. Information dissemination in a peer-to-peer setting can get bottlenecked even with non-rational algorithmic users when there is user dynamics. Here we show how to develop stable and efficient (minimum latency) peer-to-peer mechanisms for information dissemation. Having these in place, distributed optimization of functionals is an important higher level task, that we also develop low communication complexity algorithms for.

5. Strategic information transmisison between agents is the subject of a new field in economics and game theory called information design; Bayesian persuasion is sometimes also used. In real problem settings the information sender and the information receiver may have constraints (that arise from the problem), and in this context we have developed optimal signalling schemes and have also studied comparative statics in terms of the impact on receiver utiility.
